question_text:
Express the value of the following as a common fraction:
$\left(1-\frac12\right)\cdot\left(1-\frac13\right)\cdot\left(1-\frac14\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{n+1}\right) \dotsm \left(1-\frac1{100}\right)$
response:
To find the product of these terms, we can expand each term and combine like terms.

$$
\begin{aligned}
&= (1 - \frac12)(1-\frac13)(1-\frac14)\cdots (1-\frac1{n+1})\cdots (1-\frac1{100})\\
&= 1 \cdot \frac32 \cdot \frac34 \cdots \frac{\overline{n}+2}{\overline{n}+1}\cdots \frac23\\
&= \left(\frac{\overline{n}}{\overline{n}-1} - 1 \right) \cdots \left( \frac{2}{3} - 1\right)\cdot 2\\
&=\left(- \frac12 \right) \left(\frac13\right)\left(\frac14\right)\cdots \left(\frac{\overline{n}}{\overline{n}-n-1}\right)\cdots \left( \frac23\right) \\
&= -\frac{1}{2} \cdot \frac{1}{3} \cdot \frac{1}{4} \dotsm \frac{(100)(99)}{(101)(102)}\cdots\frac13\\
&=\boxed{-\frac{1}{96}}\end{aligned}
$$
